To all intents and purposes the cosmos is almost certainly infinite therefore because life has occurred on one planet subject to that qualification the probability that it exists elsewhere should be certain to commensurate extent.

Questions that cannot presently be answered in this regard however are how common interstellar life might be, what proportion of it might attain intelligence sufficient to achieve interstellar travel and whether such species might choose to conceal their existence?

With regard to an anomalous object in our Kuiper belt it might ordinarily and therefore more likely than not be comprised of a relatively pure homogenous mass consisting of one or more denser metals widely present in our solar system which could impart integrity to such a mass sufficient to withstand substantial rotational forces.

Even some forms of particularly homogenous clear water ice could potentially do so

If it was a natural interstellar anomaly it might, contain elements not otherwise present in our solar system which possess characteristics we have not previously encountered that might interfere with electromagnetic emissions.

It is also possible it could be emitting a stream or 'tail' of particles which could interfere with communications during any period a vehicle was surrounded by them.

A number of the heavier metallic elements present at quite high levels of purity in the interplanetary space of our solar system could produce strong magnetic or radioactive emissions subject to conducive conditions.

Seemingly anomalous periodic luminosity may be due to a naturally differentiated albedo ascribable to substances like gases or chemical compounds constantly migrating on it's surface.

Someone got his math wrong. If that object spins with 5,5 hours per revolution (Wikipedia), has a mean diameter of 138 km (Wikipedia) and a density of Pluto (1,8 g / cm^3) which is pretty common for a Kuiper Belt Object, then the surface gravity is 10 times greater than the centrifugal force at its equator. There is absolutely nothing to see here. This is entirely consistent with it being a piece of rubble held together by its own gravity. Of course it can also be a rock, mixed with some ice because this is what you usually find out there. High school math. No need to fantasize about spaceships, artificial gravity and what else.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/15810_Arawn

If you want to have a fast spinning object, have a look at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fast_rotators_(minor_planets) and you'll discover that there is an object with a diameter of more than 400 km that is spinning in 30 minutes (2014 JP80). That's fast. Still, no spaceship.

Also the reason why New Horizons went into safe mode was a timing problem in a command sequence. No jamming. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safe_mode_(spacecraft)

the physiological effects of the coriolis 'force' in a centrifugal chamber is inversely proportional to the size of the chamber. so obviously this doesn't discount the feasibility of simulating gravity with fictitious forces. you just need to make the spinning spacecraft much bigger than this corny little carousel in her lab. she's also not even standing perpendicular to the axis of rotation, which is... duh? no shit you're gonna get nauseous standing at a 45 degree angle. you're also still subject to earth's gravity in this dumb experiment, so your vestibular system senses that as a vector component. you need to be in space; standing perpendicular to the axis of rotation; and in a very large spinning chamber such that the difference between the radius at the level of your foot and that at the level of your head is negligible.

the reason you get nauseous is because your head is spinning much faster than your feet, due to the lower radius. equal amount of angular momentum times less distance to cover to make 1 rotation = faster angular motion relative to your feet. the nausea is proportional to the ratio thereof. so if you're in a tiny chamber whose diameter is only double your height, your head will be spinning at unbelievable speeds, rotating instead of revolving about the center, since it's IN the center. say it's slightly wider than that. now your head is no longer right in the center but it's still way closer to the center than your feet. say the radius of the chamber is 8 feet and you're 6 feet tall. well now the radius of the circle traversed by your head is 2 feet and the radius of the circle traversed by your feet is 8 feet. therefore the ratio is 4, which is an extreme ratio.

now imagine the radius of the chamber is 50 feet, something more realistic for a contemporary spacecraft. the radius of the circle traversed by your head is 44 feet, and that of the circle traversed by your feet is 50 feet. same difference of 6, equal to your height, but the ratio is only 1.136. now imagine we're doing real long-distance space travel. after all, aside from conducting experiments to answer these very questions of practicality, we have no reason to even build a centrifugal chamber in a spaceship if it's not being used for very long-distance, probably interstellar travel but at the very least travel to the outer planetary region. in that case it's more likely the chamber would have a radius of 100 feet or more.

most futurist models like the dyson ring envisioned a chamber with a radius of many, many miles, because obviously that would be the most livable situation. they imagined this not just as a spacecraft for astronauts to fly in but an actual home, a moving colony or an ark that could carry entire populations to other solar systems, not arriving until perhaps 10 generations have been born and died on the ring. so for all practical purposes, an artificial planet. you know, kinda like the video game halo. obviously it's not realistic that humans could construct such things until we have a lot of space infrastructure. in particular, the equivalent of shipyards and dry docks in permanent orbit. maybe a space elevator. but getting to that point doesn't require figuring out "artificial gravity." artificial gravity is only necessary for extremely long spaceflights. a shipyard satellite could be built in low earth orbit without anyone spending more than a month in space.

so realistically speaking it's probably more likely that we'll start building spacecraft IN space before we start sending manned missions to the far reaches of the solar system and beyond. in other words, we won't run into the artificial gravity problem until after we have the technology to construct massive space arks larger than modern cruise ships or aircraft carriers. that's not just because it's not worth sending manned spacecraft past neptune if you can't build a giant centrifugal chamber into them. it's also because there are serious limits to the kinds of spacecraft that can escape earth. the velocities required to get from the ground to the thermosphere are immense. it's just not realistic for a rocket to carry a full crew and life support and experiments AND enough fuel to escape earth's pull AND enough to get back home.

to start traveling between planets in any meaningful sense we will need new kinds of spacecraft that are much more efficient, and can afford to be much more efficient because they don't need the immense burst of work to get from stationary on the ground into orbit. once we have docks in space we can build much larger spacecraft that are "born" in space, craft that don't need to escape earth's intense surface gravity. they'll require much less energy to reach the same momentum if they launch from orbit instead of on earth. a space elevator is often seen as a realistic way of getting this started, because it obviates the need for a reentry vehicle. you'd just return to orbit, dock your craft at the shipyard, then take the adjoined space elevator back to earth's surface, on foot.

so even pretending artificial gravity wasn't a problem, this is the direction any spacefaring civilization is going to go anyway. and it just happens to be the direction that enables enormous ships of exactly the kind necessary to produce artificial gravity. if ships are gonna be built in space anyway, it'll be much more realistic to build them to such sizes that they can support a 500-foot diameter centrifuge. obviously building most things in space is harder than building them on earth. the vacuum creates just as many new problems as the weightlessness solves. but building such craft on earth is not an option in the first place because they would be too big to escape earth with rocket propulsion technology, even with nuclear propulsion actually.

the best we could do is build most of the small parts on earth and then ferry them up to a dry dock in space where they're assembled into the kind of massive, extremely aerodynamically inefficient structure that could never make it through earth's atmosphere in one piece, but would have the best chance of bringing human populations to deep space. with that being the case it's extremely unlikely that humans will ever use centrifuges smaller than 100ft diameters for anything except experiments on simulating gravity with fictitious forces, or on the coriolis effect on physiology.

They make SO many INCORRECT statements and assumptions its not even funny.  At around the 5 min mark, in a rotating environment you would be standing and living on the SIDES of an object, NOT in the center. So that sideways force would be DOWN to you, you would NOT be fighting against any sideways momentum because there would be none, and objects would NOT bend to the side but go straight DOWN just like in real gravity. Motion sickness is dependent on the size relation between you and whatever your on, so if the object is not much bigger then you then your going to get sick, BUT if the craft was say the size of State then there would be NO motion sickness, in fact you more then likely wouldn't even be able to tell it was spinning AT ALL. In a spinning environment on earth you end up with TWO forces on you, Gravity pulling you down and the spinning force pushing you sideways, the human body wasn't meant to cope with that. But in space on a spinning craft you would have only ONE, the spinning force pushing you down just like gravity on earth. Also, the larger the object is, the slower it would need to spin in order to generate 1G of gravity, so an object miles or tens of miles across would only need to spin once or twice every few hours and a human person wouldn't even notice it. Another thing is that humans DO NOT NEED exactly 1G of gravity to live comfortably, something around 60%-75% earth gravity would be sufficient for humans to live on with VERY little if any effect on them, so the space craft would need to spin even slower. So this argument that humans are far away from creating spinning craft is absurd. We could do it TOMORROW if we wanted to and had an easier way of getting the materials into space to build something that large. Plus a large caft could have its living quarters stationed closer to the outer edges where the gravity would be closer to earth's and areas for storage or work closer to the center where gravity would be lower, making working and moving large amounts of materials or objects easier.

That's what happens when you have neuropsychologist studying gravity. First of all for the experiment to be remotely valid it would have to be conducted in zero gravity. On earth you have two forces acting on your body when you're spinning. The "normal" everyday gravity pulling you downward and the centripetal force pushing you away from the axis. Coriolis effect was present only because the diameter of the spinning object was too small. You need an object that will complete one revolution in a few hours not every six seconds. Her experiment is pointless. Then she talks about vomiting in space and how disastrous it would be. If you have spin gravity it would be no more disastrous than vomiting on earth. Vomit would fall to the ground you're standing on. Just because you're standing inside a spinning structure in space it would not float away. Same spin gravity pushing you to the floor would push it down as well.

There is one valid point however. If you have a cylindrical object (a large tube or pipe) inside of which you're creating spin gravity or artificial gravity by spinning the cylinder the gravity would decrease the farther from the edge of the cylinder you went. So if there is 1G at ground level, if you built an apartment building inside such a space habitat the gravity would be less in the 5th floor than on ground level. And it would continue to decrease the closer to the axis (middle of the cylinder) you would get. If you reached the center of the cylinder you would become weightless and get stuck there. And if the cylinder was completely smooth on the inside and you took a fast motorcycle and race it in the opposite direction of the spin and could reach the same speed as the rotational speed of the cylinder you would eventually become weightless, because you would counteract the spin effect - you'd be stuck in the same spot on the cylinder while it spins underneath you making you weightless for a split second, then you would lose speed since you're wheels have no traction and fall back down. Could be a really cool sport racing inside of a space habitat.

Another weird thing would be that by looking up you'd see your neighbors hanging upside down right above you. But you'd need a good pair of binoculars because they would be miles above you in a realistic setting. The diameter of the cylinder would need to be miles. Otherwise everyone would get sick. It's actually not that difficult to calculate how wide the cylinder would have to be. Otherwise the difference in gravity by your head and at your feet would be too big, since you're head is lets say 6 foot of the ground the gravity there would be a little less than at your feet. That's why you need a large ratio between average human height and the diameter of the habitat so the difference is negligible and it would not be detected. Theoretically if you had a 10 foot diameter (and you wouldn't get sick immediately) your head would reach the center of the room/object and become weightless while the rest of your body would experience different kinds of gravity. If that's not vomit inducing I don't know what is.

But in the end I'd like to remind this neuropsychologist that earth spins. And very fast at that. Yet we don't experience any sickness because of it. So clearly we can tolerate spin. It's all about ratios, speed and revolutions.

This whole thing strikes me as nonsense. There's nothing at all strange about a rock rotating as it floats in space; they pretty much all do that.

However, if it's rotating to produce artificial gravity the numbers don't add up. If it rotates in 5.5 hours and the surface is moving at 50 MPH, it must be about 275 miles in circumference, about 44 miles in radius. Centrifugal force = the square of the speed divided by the radius, so we're looking at 73 feet per second squared, or 5378, divided by about 232,000. That's about .023 feet per second per second. That's .00072 gees, 1/1389 the strength of Earth's surface gravity. Why bother to produce such a weak force?

"On November 2, 2015, New Horizons imaged KBO 15810 Arawn with the LORRI instrument from 280 million km away (170 million mi; 1.9 AU), showing the shape of the object and one or two details. This KBO was again imaged by the LORRI instrument on April 7–8, 2016, from a distance of 111 million km (69 million mi; 0.74 AU). The new images allowed the science team to further refine the location of 15810 Arawn to within 1,000 km (620 mi) and to determine its rotational period of 5.47 hours."

"On July 4, 2015, New Horizons experienced a software anomaly and went into safe mode, preventing the spacecraft from performing scientific observations until engineers could resolve the problem. On July 5, NASA announced that the problem was determined to be a timing flaw in a command sequence used to prepare the spacecraft for its flyby, and the spacecraft would resume scheduled science operations on July 7. The science observations lost because of the anomaly were judged to have no impact on the mission's main objectives and minimal impact on other objectives."

So this TV episode just cooks up some conspiracy theory about something we know almost nothing certain about, just to have a pseudo-scientific alien-invasion story plot. Uh-huh. All we really know is there's a strange spinning object (a rock smaller than a dwarf planet, more like an asteroid) and coincidentally, our probe had an electronics or signaling glitch, with no known real connection between the two. Meh. The speculation that low-gravity aliens could be blobs with tentacles is no more than a scientific guess. (Low-grav lifeforms might have a wide range of body plans, just as much or more than our Earth-gravity lifeforms do.) Until we find (or they find) alien lifeforms, we won't know. The video was posted 2021-06-09. Four days later, I'd guess that rock hasn't changed orbit to pursue our probe or come to invade Earth. Chances are, it's an asteroid spinning around, iwith no sneaky, hostile aliens inside. So far, humans seem to be the only ones thinking about being sneaky and hostile. Could say a lot about humans. Thing is, we have zero real idea of what real aliens might think and feel and do or what they might look like, or if they are at all compatible with Earth or Earth life. Maybe they like someplace else better, if they are anywhere around here. Maybe they've scanned our outgoing signals and have sense enough to stay away from such a primitive, hostile species, at least unless we can ever outgrow our more idiotic fear-and-hate tendencies and act in a mature, responsible, less trigger happy way. But then, we really don't know how aliens might view us or what they are like, if they exist anywhere close enough to get here.

Problem is, only the habitat vessel must spin for artificial gravity, what you see from the outside is just the micrometeorite and radiation shield and would not spin or would counter spin very slowly to neutralize the angular momentum of the spinning habitat unit within.   An actual spacecraft with an artificial gravity habitat would not show anything spinning from the outside or would be counter spinning very slowly as the radiation shields would be at least 95% of the mass.   An example of this is Discovery 1 on Arthur C. Clarke's 2001 A Space Odyssey has an internal spinning section but nothing on the outside spins.   Whatever spins is subjected to the artificial gravity and hence must have more tensile strength than the rest of the spaceship so the spinning section would be kept to a minimum.   You would not spin the entire space craft if you can avoid doing so.
